title: Are there ionic compounds with low melting point? - Quora

response.answer_text: Indeed there are. In fact there is an entire class of materials called “ionic liquids”, which are liquid at room temperature. They are not what you would classically think of as a “salt” (ie, a metal halide). They are typically organic molecules designed so that they don’t “pack” into a nice lattice like a regular salt does. Ionic liquid - Wikipedia They are becoming useful recently as an electrolyte in various battery technologies

With increase in degree of covalency in the bond the melting point of the “ionic compound “ decreases..take the eg of HgI. The compound has a degree of ionicity in its bond. But the Hg which has a pseudo noble gas configuration has a strong ionic potential polarising the large iodide ion to increase the covalency of the bond..result: melting point of~260C.. compare that to NaCl which has ~800C.
